bestBHT.bht: Barabbas, the leader of a band of rioters and murderers, was bound with them and presented as an option to the people by Pilate instead of Jesus. The priests and people, in a shocking turn of events, chose a murderer over Jesus. It is significant to note that Barabbas being part of a group of murderers is unique to Mark's account and distinguishes it from the narratives in Matthew and Luke. The term insurrection carries the weight of a crime that Roman governors like Pilate were particularly vigilant in punishing.

Henry Alford: The circumstance that Barabbas was one of a set of murderers...is peculiar to our narrative, and shews that it is not compiled from Matthew and Luke.
Marvin Vincent: Them that had made insurrection with him [συστασιαστων] . Fellow - rioters.
But the better texts read stasiastwn, rioters, omitting the sun with (fellow) : and the Rev. accordingly omits with him.
Who [οιτινες] . Denoting a class of criminals.
Philip Schaff: Mark 15:7. With them that had made insurrection, etc. Peculiar to Mark. Barabbas, doubtless the leader, was one of these insurgents and murderers.
Archibald T. Robertson: Bound with them that had made insurrection.
Barabbas was the leader of these rioters and was bound with them.
Murder usually goes with such rioters and the priests and people actually chose a murderer in preference to Jesus.
John Gill: He had been at the head of a seditious mob, and he and his accomplices were taken and put in prison.
Though, no doubt, he was guilty of murder as well as they.
From the time that murderers increased, the slaying of the red heifer ceased.
John Wesley: Insurrection — A crime which the Roman governors, and Pilate in particular, were more especially concerned and careful to punish.

bhtAttempts.bht: Barabbas, the leader of a band of rioters and murderers, was bound with them and presented as an option to the people by Pilate instead of Jesus. The priests and people, in a shocking turn of events, chose a murderer over Jesus. It is significant to note that Barabbas being part of a group of murderers is unique to Mark's account and distinguishes it from the narratives in Matthew and Luke. The term insurrection carries the weight of a crime that Roman governors like Pilate were particularly vigilant in punishing.

Barabbas, the leader of a band of rioters and murderers, was bound with them and presented as an option to the people. The priests and people chose a murderer in preference to Jesus. This detail, unique to Mark's narrative and not found in Matthew or Luke, highlights the gravity of the situation. Pilate, being concerned with punishing insurrections, offered the crowd a choice between Jesus and Barabbas. The people's decision reveals the lengths to which they went to reject Jesus.

Barabbas, the leader of a group of rioters and murderers, was bound with them and presented as an alternative to Jesus. The people chose a murderer over Jesus, a shocking decision that underscores their rejection of him. This distinctive detail, found only in Mark's account, sets it apart from Matthew and Luke. The term insurrection carries weight as a crime that Roman governors were particularly concerned with punishing, making Pilate's offering even more significant. The people's choice demonstrates the extent to which they preferred a criminal over Jesus.

Barabbas, the leader of a group of rioters and murderers, was bound with them and presented as an option instead of Jesus. Surprisingly, the people decided to choose a murderer over Jesus. This unique detail in Mark's narrative highlights the gravity of the situation and distinguishes it from the accounts in Matthew and Luke. The term insurrection underscores the seriousness of the crime that Roman governors, including Pilate, were particularly concerned with punishing. The people's decision reflects their ultimate rejection of Jesus.

Barabbas, the leader of a band of rioters and murderers, was bound with them and offered as a choice instead of Jesus. Astonishingly, the people favored a murderer over Jesus. This unique detail in Mark's account distinguishes it from Matthew and Luke and emphasizes the severity of the situation. The term insurrection highlights the crime that Roman governors, such as Pilate, diligently sought to punish. The people's decision reveals the extent of their rejection of Jesus in favor of a criminal.
